- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_open:
```c
int metal_open(const char *path, int shm)
{
	const int flags = O_RDWR | O_CREAT | O_CLOEXEC;
	const int mode = S_IRUSR | S_IWUSR;
	int fd;

	if (!path || !strlen(path))
		return -EINVAL;

	fd = shm ? shm_open(path, flags, mode) : open(path, flags, mode);
	return fd < 0 ? -errno : fd;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No compiler language extensions are used in the provided code. The code only uses standard C constructs (constant int declarations, conditional operator, function calls, pointer checks, return expressions). Identifiers and APIs present (open, shm_open, O_RDWR, O_CREAT, O_CLOEXEC, S_IRUSR, S_IWUSR, errno, EINVAL, strlen) are either standard C library functions/macros or POSIX/platform APIs — these are platform/library features, not compiler language extensions. There are no vendor-specific language features (for example GCC nested functions, statement expressions, typeof, asm blocks, attribute syntaxes, or other documented compiler extensions) present in the snippet, so nothing requires investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
